title: How to Make "Georgia Ice Cream"

steps.headline: Get a pot with a lid that is large enough to hold the water plus room for the grits.
steps.description: The grits doesn't take up much space. The amount of water determines how runny your grits will be. For "Georgia Ice Cream", we want it to be a bit soupy, the consistency of soft ice cream.

steps.headline: Add the water to the pot and put it on the stove.
steps.description: Turn the heat all the way up to get the water boiling as fast as you can.

steps.headline: Add a little salt to the water.
steps.description: Use your judgment. The salt causes the water to boil at a higher temperature, as well as stratifying your personal taste.

steps.headline: Add sugar or sweetener to suit your taste.
steps.description: If serving to several people with different sweetener preference, stir in the sweetener when served.

steps.headline: Add butter to your heart's content.
steps.description: The butter gives it a creamy flavor. Adding it to the water at this time will permit it to inundate the grits and keep it from getting lumpy.

steps.headline: As soon as the water comes to a full boil, add the grits and stir like crazy.
steps.description: The grits try to pop out of the pot. Use a long handled spoon.

steps.headline: Reduce the heat to a low setting.
steps.description: For a gas stove, wait about 30 seconds and put it on medium to low.

steps.headline: Let the grits boil for about a minute while stirring then cover and let simmer.
Continue to stir occasionally.The grits should remain on the heat until they are tender.
steps.description: This depends on the type of grits (Quick, 5-Minute, or the real thing).

steps.headline: Serve in a bowl with more butter on top.
